title: Gareth Southgate moves to ease tensions over racism protocol confusion
text:
England were caught in an explosive race row on Thursday after Bulgarian football chiefs made an official complaint to UEFA amid fears of racial abuse during Monday's clash in Sofia.

Gareth Southgate's side face the Czech Republic here in Prague tonight where victory will book their place at Euro 2020 – but the clash has been overshadowed by a letter sent to European football's governing body by the president of the Bulgarian Football Union Borislav Mihaylov which criticises England's behaviour.

Former Bulgaria goalkeeper Mihaylov has written to UEFA General Secretary Theodore Theodoridis, warning that what they describe as the FA's fixation with racism in Bulgaria could increase tension.

England's qualifiers have been overshadowed by a racism row with Bulgarian football chiefs

Borislav Mihaylov, the president of the Bulgarian Football Union, has complained to UEFA

Southgate and his staff are preparing his side for away trips to Czech Republic and Bulgaria

Speaking last month England boss Gareth Southgate expressed concerns that his players could face potential racial abuse in Sofia, while black players such as Tammy Abraham and Fikayo Tomori have discussed the likelihood of taunts earlier this week — which has intensified Bulgaria's anger.

Part of the Vasil Levski Stadium will be closed on Monday night as punishment after Bulgaria fans were found guilty of racist behaviour against Kosovo and the Czech Republic in June.

Southgate, who suggested his players will respect the UEFA's three-step protocol if there are racial flashpoints, moved to ease tensions on Thursday.

England's players have spoken out, saying they will follow UEFA's racism protocols if abused

He said: 'I can totally understand why the Bulgarian president feels as he does because we have purely been responding honestly to questions we've been asked.

'That will then be relayed however it may be relayed in Bulgaria, and the way that that's pitched could appear provocative or appear that we're the people who are laying the subject on the table.

'So, if I was him, and I was only reading those quotes and not knowing the context of why the things were said and the responses were said, then I would feel probably as he does.

'We are not trying to create a situation at all, far from it. We're all hoping that over the next 72 hours, we're just talking about two football matches.

'I think both countries would have a strong desire for that and I have to say again, we don't look at other countries in a way that we don't shine a mirror on our own.

'What happened in Hartlepool a couple of weeks ago was probably worse than things I've seen or heard about in many other countries in the world. So, I think we have to be very careful in how we cover everything.'

Southgate has been trying to ease tensions, saying they're not trying to fan the flames

In his letter to UEFA, Mihaylov wrote: 'The Bulgarian Football Union, the Bulgarian general public and I find offensive due to unjust branding of the local spectators as people inclined to discriminatory behaviour.

'We feel that this fixation on potential incidents during the game in Sofia does not do justice to the Bulgarian supporters, the general public and to the extreme efforts and measures that we have taken in order to ensure a fair and safe environment for a true footballing spectacle.'

Meanwhile, Southgate is set to keep faith with Michael Keane at centre back despite his poor night in England's 5-3 win over Kosovo last month, while Kieran Trippier hopes to play, ahead of Trent Alexander-Arnold, at right back.

Mason Mount will play in an advanced midfield role for his full England debut, with Jordan Henderson and Declan Rice also in midfield.
